name: Stripe
title: Stripe

children.text: With Stripe modules in Make, you can manage the payment intents, customers, refunds, payouts, balance, invoices, invoice items, and payment links in your Stripe account.
To use the Stripe modules, you must have a Stripe account. You can create an account at
for a list of available endpoints.
To establish the connection, you can choose to connect with your Stripe API key or with Stripe OAuth.
If you choose to connect with your Stripe API key, you must first

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: obtain your API key in your Stripe account

children.text: obtain your API key in your Stripe account
Establish the connection with Stripe in Make
To establish the connection in Make:
Log in to your Make account, add a Stripe module to your Make, and click
Note: If you add a module with an
field, enter a name for the connection.
Depending on your choice of Connection type, enter the following information:
and enter your custom app client credentials. You can find your secret keys in the
. If requested, use the following Redirect URI when creating your custom app:
If prompted, authenticate your account and confirm access.
You have successfully established the connection. You can now edit your
and add more Stripe modules. If your connection requires reauthorization at any point, follow the connection renewal steps

data.label: here
data.overridedLabel: here

children.text: Obtain your API key in Stripe
To obtain your API key from your Stripe account:
Log in to your Stripe account.
In the upper right corner, click
Providing this key to another website
. Then do one of the following:
Define permissions for your restricted API key. Proceed to the step 7.
, insert the name for the API key.
Select the access level for needed permissions.
value shown and store it in a safe place.
You will use this value in the
You do not have to add the webhooks in the Stripe as it is automatically done for you once you add and save an instant trigger module to your Make.
Triggers when a given event occurs.
Enter a name for the webhook.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Select the group and the events which you want to watch.
Select the checkbox if you want this endpoint should receive events from connected accounts (true), or from your account (false).
Enter the version of the API to which events to be sent that this endpoint will be generated with this Stripe Version instead of your account’s default Stripe Version.
This app uses webhooks to trigger a Make when an event occurs instantly. All webhook modules have an
When you create a Stripe webhook in Make, it is attached automatically and requires no additional set up
Performs an arbitrary authorized API call.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: For the list of available endpoints, refer to the
Select the HTTP method you want to use:
to retrieve information for an entry.
to make a partial entry update.
Enter the desired request headers. You don't have to add authorization headers; we already did that for you.
Enter the body content for your API call.
The following API call returns all the events from your Stripe account:
Matches of the search can be found in the module's
In our example, 10 events were returned:
Retrieves a list of payment intents or filters by customer ID.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Enter the Customer ID whose payment intents you want to list. You can search the customer using their email address.
Set the maximum number of payment intents Make should return during one Make execution cycle.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Enter the amount to be collected by this Payment Intent. A positive integer represents how much to charge in the
. For example, 100 cents to charge $1.00 or 100 to charge ¥100, a zero-decimal currency. The minimum amount is $0.50 US or
. The amount value supports up to eight digits. For example, a value of 99999999 for a USD charge of $999,999.99.
Enter the three-digit currency applicable for the payment intent.
Enter the details of the payment intent.
Enter the email address to which the payment intent recipient should be sent.
Select whether you want to confirm the payment intent immediately.
Select the payment methods for this payment intent.
Select the Customer ID to whom this payment intent receipt should go.
Create a Payment Method and attach it to this Payment Intent
Enter the recipient's area postal code.
Enter the courier service name. For example,
Enter the details of the payment intent. For non-card charges, you can use this value as the complete description that appears on your customer’s statements. A maximum of 22 characters is allowed.

Enter the statement details that appear on the customer's statement. Concatenated with the statement descriptor prefix and statement descriptor to form the complete statement descriptor. A maximum of 22 characters is allowed.
Enter the ID that you associate with the cart or customer session in your application - when creating the Payment Intent to avoid erroneously creating duplicate Payment Intents for the same purchase.
Select the payment intent capture method:
Select the payment intent confirmation method:

Select whether you want to Stripe SDK for sending a confirmation about the payment intent. This is applicable only for Stripe Connect and only when using iOS or Android SDKs to handle additional authentication steps.
Enter the transfer group associated with the payment intent. This field is only applicable if you are using Stripe Connect.
Enter the application fee amount for the payment intent. This is applicable for Stripe Connect Only. For more information, see the Payment Intents
Enter the Stripe Account ID to whom the payment intent belongs. This field is for Stripe Connect Only. For more information, see the Payment Intents
Enter the amount of this payment intent to send to the destination account.

that you can attach to an object. This can be useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured format. Individual keys can be unset by posting an empty value to them. All keys can be unset by posting an empty value to
Retrieves the details of a Payment Intent that has previously been created.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Select the Payment Intent ID whose details you want to retrieve. You can find the Payment Intent ID on the Payments page.
Confirms a payment intent by its ID. Upon confirmation, the payment intent will attempt to initiate a payment.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Select the Payment Intent ID whose details you want to retrieve. You can find the Payment Intent ID on the Payments page.
Enter the email address to which the payment intent recipient should be sent to.
Select the payment method option to attach to this Payment Intent:
Create a Payment Method and attach it to this Payment Intent
Select the Payment Method ID to attach to the payment intent.
to the Payment Intent’s Customer if present, after the Payment Intent, is confirmed and any required actions from the user are complete. If no Customer was provided, the payment method can still be
to a Customer after the transaction completes.
Select the payment method. For example,
Enter the recipient's billing street address.
Enter the recipient's billing street address.
Enter the recipient's area postal code.
Enter the billing address contact's email address.
Enter the billing address contact's name.
Enter the billing address's phone number.
Add a set of Key-Pair values for the payment intent.
Enter the recipient's shipping street address.
Enter the recipient's area postal code.
Enter the courier service name. For example,
Select the payment methods for this payment intent. For example, card,
Select the preferred language for the Bancontact payment method.
Select whether the payment installation configuration is enabled for this payment intent. This applies only to Mexico Only. For more information, see the
Select the payment network. For example,
Select the option for 3D secure payment:
Stripe strongly recommends that you rely on our SCA Engine to automatically prompt your customers for authentication based on risk level and
. However, if you wish to request 3D Secure based on logic from your fraud engine, provide this option. Read the guide on
for more information on how this configuration interacts with Radar and the SCA Engine.
Select the preferred language for the SOFORT payment method.
Select whether the customer is not in your checkout flow during this payment attempt, and therefore is unable to authenticate. This parameter is intended for Make where you collect card details and
Select whether to fail the payment attempt if the Payment Intent transitions into required action. This parameter is intended for simpler integrations that do not handle customer actions, like
Select an option to mandate the payment intent:
Enter the Mandate ID to be used for this payment only. The ID is your account's secret key.
Enter the IP address from which the Mandate was accepted by the customer.
Enter the user agent of the browser from which the Mandate was accepted by the customer.
Enter the time at which the customer has accepted the mandate.

Enter the URL address to redirect the customer back to after they authenticate or cancel their payment on the payment method’s app or site. If you prefer to redirect to a mobile application, you can alternatively supply an application URI scheme.
Captures an existing uncaptured payment intent by its ID.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Enter the Payment Intent ID you want to capture. You can search for the payment Intent ID using Customer ID.
Enter the amount to capture from the Payment Intent. The amount must be less than or equal to the original amount. Any additional amount will be automatically refunded. Defaults to the full

Enter the details of the payment intent that appears on the card statement. For non-card charges, you can use this value as the complete description that appears on your customer’s statements. The description must be at most 22 characters long.

Enter the details of the payment intent that appears on the card statement. For non-card charges, you can use this value as the complete description that appears on your customer’s statements. Must be at most 22 characters long.

Enter the amount of the application fee (if any) that will be requested to be applied to the payment and transferred to the application owner’s Stripe account. The amount of the application fee collected will be capped at the total payment amount. This is applicable to Stripe Connect only. For more information, see the Payment Intents
The amount that will be transferred automatically when a charge succeeds. The amount is capped at the total transaction amount and if no amount is set, the full amount is transferred.
Updates the specified payment intent by setting the values of the parameters passed.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Select the Payment Intent ID whose details you want to retrieve. You can find the Payment Intent ID on the Payments page.

Enter the amount to charge in the smallest currency unit. For example, 100 cents to charge $1.00 or 100 to charge ¥100, a zero-decimal currency. The minimum amount is $0.50 US or equivalent in charge currency.
The amount must be lower than or equal to 99999999.

children.text: Enter the details of the customer.
Enter the customer's shipping street address.
Enter the customer's shipping street address.
Enter the customer's area postal code.
Enter the contact's name at the shipping address.
Enter the shipping address contact phone number.
Enter the customer's Payment Method ID.
that you can attach to an object. This can be useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured format.

Enter an integer amount in paise/cents that represent the customer’s current balance. This amount affects the customer’s future invoices. A negative amount represents a credit that decreases the amount due on an invoice; a positive amount increases the amount due on an invoice.
Enter the customer's Coupon ID. If you provide a coupon code, the customer will have a discount applied on all recurring charges. Charges you create through the API will not have a discount.
Enter the prefix for the customer used to generate unique invoice numbers. The prefix must be 3–12 uppercase letters or numbers.
Add the custom fields and values for the customer. For example,
Enter the default Payment Method ID of the customer. This is used in customers' invoices.
Enter the information that appears in the footer of the invoice.
Enter the sequence to be used on the customer's next invoice.
Add the customer's preferred communication languages.
Enter the customer's Promotion Code ID used to avail of discounts. The customer will have a discount applied on all recurring payments. Charges created through the API will not have a discount.

Enter the Source ID from where the customer is registering with. When using payment sources created via the Token or Sources APIs, the passing source will create a new source object, make it the new customer default source, and delete the old customer default if one exists.
Select the tax exemption option applicable to the customer:
Add the customer's Tax ID data:
Select the tax type. For example, EU-VAT.
Retrieves the details of an existing customer.

data.label: Stripe
data.overridedLabel: Establish a connection to your Stripe account.

children.text: Select the charge for which you want to create a refund.
Enter the amount to be refunded. A positive integer in the
. For example, 100 cents to charge $1.00 or 100 to charge ¥100, a 0-decimal currency representing the amount to refund. You can only refund up to the unrefunded amount remaining of the charge.
Select the reason for the refund. For example, duplicate.

Select whether the application fee should be refunded when refunding this charge. If a full charge refund is given, the full application fee will be refunded. Otherwise, the application fee will be refunded in an amount proportional to the amount of the charge refunded.

Select whether the transfer should be reversed when refunding this charge. The transfer will be reversed proportionally to the amount being refunded (either the entire or partial amount). A transfer can be reversed only by the application that created the charge.
Enter a set of key-value pairs that you can attach to a

object. This can be useful for storing additional information about the refund in a structured format. You can unset individual keys if you POST an empty value for that key. You can clear all keys if you POST an empty value for
Retrieves the details of an existing.

children.text: Select the Customer ID for whom invoice you want to create the invoice.
Select whether you want Stripe to perform an
of the invoice. When left unselected, the invoice’s state will not automatically advance without explicit action.
Select the option for invoice collection method:
Enter the number of days from when the invoice is created until it is due. Applicable only when the collection method is selected as Send Invoices.
Enter the date on which the payment for the invoice is due. Applicable only when collection method is Send Invoices.

Enter the Subscription ID of the invoice. If left blank, the created invoice will include all pending invoice items for the customer. If set, the created invoice will only include pending invoice items for that subscription and pending invoice items not associated with any subscription. The subscription’s billing cycle and regular subscription events won’t be affected.

that you can attach to an object. This can be useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured format. Individual keys can be unset by posting an empty value to them. All keys can be unset by posting an empty value to

Enter the application fee in cents that will be applied to the invoice and transferred to the application owner’s Stripe account. The request must be made with an OAuth key or the Stripe-Account header to take an application fee. For more information, see the application fees
Add the custom fields for the invoice:
Enter the name of the custom field. You can enter a maximum of 30 characters.
Enter the value of the custom field. You can enter a maximum of 30 characters.

Enter the default payment method ID for the invoice. It must belong to the customer associated with the invoice. If not set, defaults to the subscription’s default payment method, if any, or to the default payment method in the customer’s invoice settings.
Enter the Default Tax Rate ID.
Add the discounts applicable for the invoice:
Select the Coupon ID applicable for the invoice.
Enter an existing discount ID on the object (or one of its ancestors) to reuse.
Enter the text that appears at the footer of the invoice.
Enter the text that appears in the customer's invoice statement. If not specified and this invoice is part of a subscription, the default
will be set to the first subscription item’s product’s
Enter the account to which the invoice amount to be transferred.
Enter the amount to be transferred.
Retrieves the details of an existing invoice with the given ID.

on the invoice does not apply to this invoice item. Pass an empty string to remove previously-defined tax rates.

on the invoice do not apply to this invoice item. Pass an empty string to remove previously-defined tax rates.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
